name: The Breeders

At the time, Deal was the bassist of the Pixies and Donelly was the guitarist of the Throwing Muses, but they were both keen on proving themselves as singers and songwriters. Reportedly, the original plan was to record an album of songs written by Deal, followed by an album of songs written by Donelly. Kim Deal asked her twin sister Kelley to join The Breeders in 1992; soon after, Donelly left the group to form Belly. Since then, The Breeders have toured and recorded intermittently, undergoing diverse line-up changes, the only stable members being Kim and Kelley Deal.

After a stint by the New Orleans Rhythm Kings he formed another group which played at Friar's Inn in Chicago. He played regularly in New Orleans in the 1930s and moved to Mississippi in 1946, where he played with his brothers in a Dixieland jazz band until his retirement.

name: Grace La Rue

name: Mischa Spoliansky
comments: Russian-born composer, who was born into a Jewish family in Białystok, then part of the Russian Empire. After the early death of his mother the family moved to Vienna. In 1914 he had to flee to Berlin, where he made a career as a composer. When Hitler came to power in 1933, Spoliansky was forced to emigrate to London, where he began a second career as a film composer.

name: Marcellus Schiffer

name: Marianne Mendt

name: Monique Melsen

name: Wendell Harrison

name: Joseph Schmidt
comments: Popular Jewish Schlager singer and actor, born in the Bukovina province of (then) Austria-Hungary (later Rumania). He moved to Berlin in 1928, launching a successful international career. Ironically, Schmidt enjoyed his greatest successes during the rise of the German Nazis, who subsequently prohibited Jewish artists and writers from working. In 1937, he toured the United States and performed in Carnegie Hall and was immensely popular in The Netherlands and Belgium.

name: Ankie Keultjes

name: Jan Kiepura

He signed contracts with Convert Garden in London, the Opéra Comique in Paris and the Deutsche Staatsoper in Berlin and also started a film career working with Berlin's UFA and later in Hollywood.

name: Jenny Klaver
comments: Lyricist

name: Harry Hayes

He also recorded under his own name and, in the 1960s, he briefly had his own label, "Burnie."

name: Lotte Lehmann

She gave memorable performances in the operas of Richard Strauss, Richard Wagner, Ludwig van Beethoven, Puccini, Mozart and Jules Massenet. In August 1936, while in Salzburg, she discovered the Trapp Family Singers later made famous in the musical "The Sound of Music". Before Germany annexed Austria in 1938 Lehmann emigrated to the US, where she continued to sing at the San Francisco Opera and the Metropolitan Opera until 1945. She retired from the stage in 1951.

name: Percy Grainger

His father, Antonio Bagarozy, was an impresario who represented musical artists including Enrico Caruso. His brother, Armand Bagarozy, was general director of the Columbia Opera Company. Bob Bagar died in the home of his mother, Marie Bagarozy.

name: The Bitter End Singers

The group consisted of 3 women and 3 men until 1965 when they became five people as show in the picture above. This group performed a variety of music from light rock to show tunes to folk music to novelty tunes and toured the U.S., Europe and Canada for three years beginning in 1964. They released two albums and several singles.

Between 2004 and 2006 Beczała made several major international house debuts. In April 2004 he made his debut at London's Royal Opera House as the Italian tenor in "Der Rosenkavalier".

In 1953 he played and sang the role of Richard Tauber in the biopic "Du bist die Welt für mich", released in English-speaking countries as either "You Are the World for Me" or "The Richard Tauber Story".

name: Kurt Richter

He was a tenor and with  Johnny Schulz (tenor), Fritz Lowenstein (bass) and Paul Meier (baritone) he formed a group in Wedding, a locality in the borough of "Mitte" in Berlin. The four men called themselves "Die vier Wedding Boys". In 1933 the group was renamed "Die Vier Richters" and succesfully performed and recorded in various combinations and under various names.

name: Grafite

name: Max Mensing

He was involved at this time and in the early 1930s in many recordings of well-known Berliner Tanzorchester. Mensing swallowed poison in Berlin during the last days of World War II.

name: Malcolm Gets

name: Jonas Kaufmann

name: Steve Colson
comments: Born in Newark, New Jersey, pianist Colson obtained a degree in music from Northwestern University  in Evanston, Illinois, and was an early member of Chicago's Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, a collective associated with free and avant-garde jazz.  Colson eventually returned to the east coast and now lives in Montclair, New Jersey.  Colson is also a composer and a faculty member of Bloomfield College in New Jersey, and Medgar Evers College of The City University of New York; he teaches World Music, History of African American Music, Intro to Music Technology, and Piano.

name: Iqua Colson
comments: Jazz vocalist and lyricist born and raised in Chicago.  She moved to the east coast in 1982 with her spouse and works as an arts educator with the East Orange Public Schools in New Jersey.

name: The Squad

name: Household Division
aliases: The Massed Bands and Corps of Drums of the Household Divison
The Massed Bands of the Household Division
Trumpeters, Massed Bands, Pipes and Drums, and Corps of Drums of the Household Division
comments: Ceremonial duties are an important part of the British army history and tradition. The Household Division provides both ceremonial and operational support for the Crown on Royal occasions such as the State Opening of Parliament, Trooping the Colour (Queen’s Birthday Parade) and Beating Retreat.

name: Pholhas
comments: Pholhas is a Brazilian rock band from the city of São Paulo, where it was founded in 1969. The band is still active.

name: Harold Lewis

name: Peg LaCentra

In 1939 she was given her own program on NBC, "The Peg LaCentra Show". She later appeared in a number of films and episodic TV particularly dubbing non-singing actresses.

name: Lew Sherwood

name: Bert Barnes

The spring of 1932 found him on the arranging staff for Henry Hall's new BBC Dance Orchestra The following years he was providing arrangements for Bert Ambrose as well. In April 1934 he joined Ambrose & His Orchestra full time as pianist and arranger, a position he held until the end of 1937. During this period he also attended recording sessions for Jay Wilbur at "Rex" records. After World War II he moved to Australia.

name: Arthur Lally
aliases: Philip Lewis and His Dance Orchestra
comments: Musician who played the saxophone, clarinet, trombone, trumpet, piano and violin. It was as a saxophonist that he would meet success on the London dance band scene in the 1920s and 1930s. He played with the Savoy Orpheans, Bert Firman's Devonshire Restaurant Band and Ambrose, before establishing himself as a bandleader recording prolifically on Decca. Decca's director of music was Philip Lewis, who had a background in light classical music and directing theatre pit orchestras. So far as the new Decca studio group was concerned, Lewis relied heavily on Lally. All the recordings from the first two 1929 sessions (June 20th and 29th) were issued as by "Philip Lewis and his Dance Orchestra", but from the third session (July 16th, 1929) onwards the pseudonym "The Rhythm Maniacs" started to be used.  So Lally made records under his own name and a selection of pseudonyms.

name: Dion Titheradge
comments: Son of the famous English-Australian actor George Sutton Titheradge (1848–1916).  He also made his career in the theatre, making his initial debut in Newcastle in 1908. Although he was an actor, he was also a skilled producer, but he is best known as a writer for stage, especially plays, revues, sketches and film scenarios and songs. One of his most famous songs is “And Mother Came Too”.

name: Albert Plunkett
comments: The crooner Al Plunkett was one of the most famous of the soldier-entertainers with the First World War Canadian concert party "The Dumbells". On their return to Canada in 1919 Al assisted his older brother Captain Mert Plunkett in planning a Canadian tour of their successful Dumbells act, which lasted until 1932. Al's role was the suave man about town: he sang in top hat and tails, danced and performed in comic sketches.

name: The Two Gilberts
comments: The Two Gilberts were a music hall type act in the 1920's, although it is thought they only actually recorded and did not make live appearances. There is also mystery as to who they were several names have been put forward, it is generally thought that Douglas was nearly always one part of the duo and that Leslie Rome was his most common partner. Harry Cove & Billy Thompson were also mainstays of the duo at various times.
